On Wed, 2004-07-14 at 18:30, stack wrote:
> Lars Clausen wrote:
> 
> > ...
> >
> >Since there's no way to get the size of the compressed entry (AFAICS), a
> >Java-based scanning of compressed ARC files would entail reimplementing
> >the gzip reader.
> >
> >  
> >
> Yeah, the java.util.zip.GZIPInputStream implementation is a little 
> broke.  Or rather, it seems java.util.zip.Inflater is broke, the zlib 
> deflater wrapper around the native zlib library used by GZIPInputStream. 
[gzip messiness]

> 
> Study of the native gzip code, how its working around 
> end-of-gzip-member, and trying to figure exactly how Inflater works, or 
> doesn't, are next up on the agenda.

Has anyone studied how well the compression in the ARC file works
compared to how well a file system or the hardware can compress?  IMHO,
leaving the compression to the underlying layers would lessen the risk
of the file itself becoming unreadable.  Hardware compression stays with
the hardware, in-format compression can (and does) confuse people.  

-Lars
